factoid: Kutúzov turned away.
Kutúzov's eyes flitted over his face with the same smile he had used to turn from Captain Timókhin.

Kutúzov turned away with a grimace as if to say that everything Dólokhov had said to Kutúzov had long been known to Kutúzov, that Kutúzov was weary of it, and that it was not at all what Kutúzov wanted.
Kutúzov turned away and went to the carriage.
The regiment broke up into companies, which went to their appointed quarters near Braunau.
The companies hoped to receive boots and clothes and to rest after their hard marches.
The regimental commander overtook the third company on its way to its quarters and rode up to Captain Timókhin who was walking in front.
The regimental commander said to Captain Timókhin: "You won’t bear me a grudge, Prokhór Ignátych?"
After the inspection was happily over, the regimental commander’s face beamed with irrepressible delight.
The regimental commander said: "It’s in the Emperor’s service... it can’t be helped... one is sometimes a bit hasty on parade..."
The regimental commander said: "I am the first to apologize, you know me!"
The regimental commander held out his hand to Captain Timókhin.
Captain Timókhin replied: "Don’t mention it, General, as if I’d be so bold!"
Captain Timókhin’s nose grew redder as he gave a smile which showed where two front teeth were missing that had been knocked out by the butt end of a gun at Ismail.
Captain Timókhin said: "And tell Mr. Dólokhov that I won’t forget him—Dólokhov may be quite easy."
Captain Timókhin asked: "How is Dólokhov behaving himself, and in general..."
Captain Timókhin said: "As far as the service goes Dólokhov is quite punctilious, your excellency; but Dólokhov’s character..."
The regimental commander asked: "And what about Dólokhov’s character?"
Captain Timókhin answered: "Dólokhov’s character is different on different days."
Captain Timókhin said: "One day Dólokhov is sensible, well educated, and good-natured, and the next Dólokhov is a wild beast."
Captain Timókhin said: "In Poland, if you please, Dólokhov nearly killed a Jew."
The regimental commander remarked: "Oh, well, well! Still, one must have pity on a young man in misfortune. You know Dólokhov has important connections."
Captain Timókhin said: "I will, your excellency," showing by his smile that he understood the regimental commander’s wish.
The regimental commander sought out Dólokhov in the ranks and, reining in his horse, said to Dólokhov: "After the next affair... epaulettes."
Dólokhov looked round but did not say anything, nor did the mocking smile on his lips change.
The regimental commander continued: "Well, that’s all right," and added: "A cup of vodka for the men from me," so that the soldiers could hear.
The regimental commander said: "I thank you all! God be praised!"
The regimental commander rode past the company and overtook the next one.
Captain Timókhin said to the subaltern beside him: "Well, Dólokhov is really a good fellow, one can serve under him."
The subaltern said: "In a word, Dólokhov is a hearty one," laughing.
The regimental commander was nicknamed King of Hearts.
The cheerful mood of the officers after the inspection infected the soldiers.
The company marched on gaily.
The soldiers’ voices could be heard on every side.
A soldier said: "And they said Kutúzov was blind of one eye?"
Another soldier said: "And so he is! Quite blind!"
Another soldier said: "No, friend, Kutúzov is sharper-eyed than you are. Boots and leg bands... Kutúzov noticed everything..."
Another soldier said: "When he looked at my feet, friend... well, thinks I..."
Another soldier said: "And that other one with him, the Austrian, looked as if he were smeared with chalk—as white as flour! I suppose they polish him up as they do the guns."
Another soldier said: "I say, Fédeshon! Did Dólokhov say when the battles are to begin? You were near him. Everybody said that Buonaparte himself was at Braunau."
The regimental commander was very pleased.
